newsitem.title: GREECE: GREEK PPC TO PAY CUSTOMERS FINES FOR POOR SERVICE.
newsitem.headline: GREEK PPC TO PAY CUSTOMERS FINES FOR POOR SERVICE.

text.p: Greece's Public Power Corporation (PPC) announced it stands ready effective May 12 to compensate its customers in cases where it fails to provide standard services.
"Standing by the obligations assumed against its subscribers, the PPC will introduce the Charter of Obligations to Consumers on May 12 1997," the utility said in a statement.
The charter calls for providing warranties on services offered to PPC's clientele and paying fines to customers when it fails to meet certain quality standards.
Set at 5,000 drachmas ($18), the fine is of "symbolic" nature.
"The amount (5,000 drachmas) will be proof of the PPC's willingness to offer quality services and of its confidence as to personnel capabilities," it said.
The Charter of Obligations to Consumers includes services pertaining to the maximum response time for repair works, new connections and re-connections.
